East Sikkim.title: East Sikkim, Sikkim
info: Home to Gangtok, the state capital of Sikkim.
A major hub for tourism, administration, and commerce in the state.
Features the famous Tsomgo Lake (Changu Lake) and the Nathu La Pass, a border crossing with China.
The district is known for its beautiful monasteries, including Rumtek Monastery.
It plays a crucial role in the state's economy due to its connectivity and urban centers.

West Sikkim.title: West Sikkim, Sikkim
info: Considered the historical heartland of Sikkim, home to Yuksom, the first capital.
Features Pelling, a famous tourist town with stunning views of the Kanchenjunga mountain range.
The base for many of Sikkim's most popular treks, including the one to Goecha La.
Contains the ruins of Rabdentse, the second capital of the former Kingdom of Sikkim.
Known for the Khecheopalri Lake, considered sacred by both Buddhists and Hindus.

North Sikkim.title: North Sikkim, Sikkim
info: The largest of Sikkim's districts by area, but the least populated.
Famous for its breathtaking high-altitude landscapes, including Yumthang Valley (Valley of Flowers).
Home to Gurudongmar Lake, one of the highest lakes in the world, considered sacred.
Lachen and Lachung are the two main tourist towns, serving as bases for exploring the region.
The district's headquarters is Mangan, known as the 'Cardamom Capital of the World'.

South Sikkim.title: South Sikkim, Sikkim
info: The district headquarters is Namchi, which means 'Sky High' in the Sikkimese language.
Famous for the Char Dham complex (Siddheshwar Dham) in Namchi, a major Hindu pilgrimage site.
Features the giant statue of Guru Padmasambhava at Samdruptse Hill.
Known for its sprawling Temi Tea Garden, the only tea estate in Sikkim.
Considered a model district for its progress in organic farming and sanitation.
